<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 448, 782, 464]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 464, 325, 479]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 479, 504, 495]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 495, 504, 510]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 510, 380, 525]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 539, 910, 570]]<|/det|>
Answer all the questions in the space provided. If additional space is required, you should use the lined page at the end of this booklet. The question number(s) must be clearly shown.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 570, 910, 600]]<|/det|>
Give non- exact numerical answers correct to 3 significant figures, or 1 decimal place in the case of angles in degrees, unless a different level of accuracy is specified in the question.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 600, 598, 615]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 644, 608, 660]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 660, 757, 675]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 675, 440, 690]]<|/det|>
The total number of marks for this paper is 50.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 75, 92, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>2</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 73, 920, 139]]<|/det|>
Benju cycles to work each morning and he has two possible routes. He chooses the hilly route with probability 0.4 and the busy route with probability 0.6. If he chooses the hilly route, the probability that he will be late for work is \(x\) and if he chooses the busy route the probability that he will be late for work is \(2x\). The probability that Benju is late for work on any day is 0.36.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[128, 152, 156, 170]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[160, 151, 326, 170]]<|/det|>
Show that \(x = 0.225\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 152, 920, 170]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[158, 460, 186, 477]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 460, 865, 477]]<|/det|>
Given that Benju is not late for work, find the probability that he chooses the hilly route. [3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 75, 96, 92]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 73, 920, 109]]<|/det|> The speeds, in \(\mathrm{km\,h^{- 1}}\), of 90 cars as they passed a certain marker on a road were recorded, correct to the nearest \(\mathrm{km\,h^{- 1}}\). The results are summarised in the following table. <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[243, 117, 794, 164]]<|/det|>
Speed (km h⁻¹)10 - 2930 - 3940 - 4950 - 5960 - 89
Frequency1024301412
<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[128, 180, 156, 198]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[160, 180, 658, 198]]<|/det|> On the grid, draw a histogram to illustrate the data in the table. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 180, 920, 198]]<|/det|> [4] <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[245, 220, 829, 768]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[123, 73, 154, 91]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[158, 73, 811, 92]]<|/det|>
Calculate an estimate for the mean speed of these 90 cars as they pass the marker.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 73, 920, 92]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 73, 96, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>4</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 73, 806, 92]]<|/det|>
In Quarendon, \(66\%\) of households are satisfied with the speed of their wifi connection.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[126, 104, 156, 123]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[160, 104, 920, 138]]<|/det|>
Find the probability that, out of 10 households chosen at random in Quarendon, at least 8 are satisfied with the speed of their wifi connection.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 119, 920, 138]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[123, 73, 153, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 73, 920, 108]]<|/det|>
A random sample of 150 households in Quarendon is chosen. Use a suitable approximation to find the probability that more than 84 are satisfied with the speed of their wifi connection. [5]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 74, 94, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>5</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 73, 920, 139]]<|/det|>
A fair red spinner has four sides, numbered 1, 2, 3, 3. A fair blue spinner has three sides, numbered \(-1, 0, 2\). When a spinner is spun, the score is the number on the side on which it lands. The spinners are spun at the same time. The random variable \(X\) denotes the score on the red spinner minus the score on the blue spinner.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[126, 151, 154, 168]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[158, 151, 542, 168]]<|/det|>
Draw up the probability distribution table for \(X\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 151, 920, 168]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 73, 920, 123]]<|/det|>
In another forest, the heights of another type of fir tree are modelled by a normal distribution. A scientist measures the heights of 500 randomly chosen trees of this type. He finds that 48 trees are less than \(10\mathrm{~m}\) high and 76 trees are more than \(24\mathrm{~m}\) high.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 135, 151, 153]]<|/det|>
<label>(iii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 135, 734, 153]]<|/det|>
Find the mean and standard deviation of the heights of trees of this type.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 135, 920, 153]]<|/det|>
<mark>[5]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 73, 94, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>7</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[128, 73, 165, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[158, 73, 920, 108]]<|/det|>
Find the number of different ways in which the 9 letters of the word TOADSTOOL can be arranged so that all three Os are together and both Ts are together.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 87, 920, 106]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[109, 330, 143, 348]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 330, 920, 364]]<|/det|>
Find the number of different ways in which the 9 letters of the word TOADSTOOL can be arranged so that the Ts are not together.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 345, 920, 364]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 74, 153, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>(iii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 73, 920, 108]]<|/det|>
Find the probability that a randomly chosen arrangement of the 9 letters of the word TOADSTOOL has a T at the beginning and a T at the end.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 87, 920, 106]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[109, 395, 146, 413]]<|/det|>
<label>(iv)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 395, 920, 428]]<|/det|>
Five letters are selected from the 9 letters of the word TOADSTOOL. Find the number of different selections if the five letters include at least 2 Os and at least 1 T.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 412, 920, 429]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]
